alternatives.transcript: this is news team 10 the growing concern over young people smoking has gotten the attention of the cigarette manufacturers they've come out with a parent's guide to help teens cope with peer pressure the pamphlet is called tobacco helping youth say no it's the centerpiece of a national campaign to discourage smoking among teenagers

it was written with the help of several nationally known Educators familiar with the problems of Youth tobacco helping you'd say no is a booklet designed for parents to help them as they work with their young people in dealing with peer pressure how to cope with peer pressure helping them make good decisions on some very tough issues one of which is smoking

the pamphlet also has a questionnaire and parents in their teens can answer the same questions and the results are supposed to lead to a better understanding now you can write for a free copy helping youth say no the tobacco Institute p.o. box for 1130 Washington d.c. 200 18

they say kids shouldn't smoke and they've launched a multi-million dollar advertising campaign called tobacco helping youth say no it includes booklet to help parents guide their children away from cigarettes and it might surprise you to learn that they were talking about is the tobacco industry welcome Marion is Vice President of the tobacco Institute jolly and Davidson is a former teacher co-chair of Iowa's First National Association of state boards of education and

of the pamphlet recently visited our Studios how do you stop kids from smoking how are you trying to go about discouraging children from smoking well I think that really gets into the publication that we're providing that Jolly an has helped to create this is the pamphlet that's available for parents and it's called if you show help doctors helping you say know one of the things in there and anybody who's been a kid we all have at some point we'll remember peer pressure is such a part of

growing up no matter how independent no matter how solid young person you are peer pressure can still come to Bear how can you help how can parents help their children deal with peer pressure when I think that there are a variety of ways peer pressure probably is most compelling issue as to why youngsters do want to smoke or do any of the other things that constitute adult behavior and parents need to have an ongoing relationship and open communication and that's where this booklet will help parents

you say open communication what's the first thing that parents should do to try and educate their children against smoking and how early should they start I think they need to start very early I think children are very early age receive a great deal of information in school media Etc about smoking if they do not ask questions at home that I think that it behooves a parent to indeed initiate the discussion I think being what I think you need to talk about smoking talk about why children shouldn't smoke it more important

Lee you need to give youngsters answers so that indeed when their peers do suggest they smoke they have something what answers well they can handle this in a variety of ways one of the best ways to handle any behavior that you don't want to get into as a child and I'm sure you'll remember is saying oh no I I can't do that my mom would kill me so one good answer is putting the blame on the parent my shoulders are broad much broader than my youngsters another way Perhaps it is

humor but I think that the best thing that a parent can do is instill a great deal of self confidence in their younger youngster because self-confidence is the best antidote for resisting peer pressure do you hope that children never become smokers even as adults I think that when they become adults as I would say to my own children that is their decision to make but I firmly believe as the tobacco industry believes that youngsters should not spoke and that's why I think this booklet

it which is free of charge by the way is so valuable for parents Walker merryman there are some critics who would say that this is nothing more than blood money from the tobacco Institute that is smoking becomes so less acceptable in our society today that it's far more frowned upon you see it less at parties less at Social Gatherings that this is the tobacco industry's way of trying to make itself look good what's your response to that I don't think there's any way through this program or anything else I can think of that we can really communicate very well with our critics

that's not what we're trying to do here we're trying to communicate with tens of millions of parents through a national advertising campaign to tell them that there is a way for them to help their youngsters resist peer pressure that's part of the program the other part of the program working with the retail Community the people who sell cigarettes putting signs up which tell kids they can't buy cigarettes there and I think that works very well welcome merryman vice-president of the tobacco Institute and jolly and Davidson thanks very
much for joining us thank you
